comment.author: 25695066@N00
comment._content:
Pilot Arthur V. Rogers standing in front of the Bryant Monoplane "Angel of Los Angeles" (reg. X705). The aircraft was constructed on behalf of famed architect Leland A. Bryant for entry in the Dole Air Race, which featured a $35,000 prize for the first non-stop flight from Oakland, California to Honolulu, Hawaii.  

On August 11, 1927, Bryant would take "Angel of Los Angeles" up for a test flight from Western Air Field in Montebello, CA.  Approximately two-miles from air field the aircraft reportedly nose-dived toward the ground.  Witnesses reported Bryant jumping from the aircraft as it dove, but he was killed when his parachute failed to open.
